STATE OF MICHIGAN
GRETCHEN WHITMER DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR LANSING DIRECTOR
August 19, 2022
Cathey Prudhomme
Eagle Village Inc
4507 170th Avenue
Hersey, MI 49639
RE: License #: CI670290156
Investigation #: 2022C0227013
Eagle Village Ashmun-Sherk
Dear Mrs. Prudhomme:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at (616) 204-6992.

Sincerely,
Jennifer Pastorick, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
305 Ludington St.
Escanaba, MI 49829
(906) 280-3979
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CI670290156
Investigation #: 2022C0227013
Complaint Receipt Date: 08/09/2022
Investigation Initiation Date: 08/09/2022
Report Due Date: 10/08/2022
Licensee Name: Eagle Village Inc
Licensee Address: 4507 170th Avenue
Hersey, MI 49639
Licensee Telephone #: (231) 832-2234
Administrator: Cathey Prudhomme, Administrator
Licensee Designee: Cathey Prudhomme, Designee
Name of Facility: Eagle Village Ashmun-Sherk
Facility Address: 17220 W. Village Rd.
Hersey, MI 49639
Facility Telephone #: (231) 832-7265
Original Issuance Date: 09/04/2007
License Status: REGULAR
Effective Date: 05/19/2022
Expiration Date: 05/18/2024
Capacity: 24
Program Type: CHILD CARING INSTITUTION, PRIVATE
1

II. ALLEGATION(S)
Violation
Established?
Youth was sent on a home pass at the end of July/first week of Yes
August 2022. Staff did not provide her with her Vyvanse
prescription medication. She ran out the last day of July and did
not have it on August 1st or 2nd. She became dysregulated during
the home pass and assaultive. The lack of medication may have
been a contributing factor to her behavior.
III. METHODOLOGY
08/09/2022 Special Investigation Intake
2022C0227013
08/09/2022 Special Investigation Initiated - Telephone
Spoke with Assigned DCWL consultant
08/09/2022 Contact - Telephone call made
Spoke with Foster Care Worker/ Complainant
08/10/2022 Contact - Telephone call received
Spoke with Placement Collaboration Specialist
08/10/2022 Inspection Completed On-site
Interview youth, staff, obtain documents
08/10/2022 Contact - Document Received
MAR and policy
08/11/2022 Contact - Telephone call received
Received message from foster care worker
08/12/2022 Contact - Telephone call made
Left message for foster care worker
08/16/2022 Contact- Face to Face
Interview staff and pre exit with Vice President
08/16/2022 Document Received
ALLEGATION:
Youth was sent on a home pass at the end of July/first week of August 2022. Staff
did not provide her with her Vyvanse prescription medication. She ran out the last
day of July and did not have it on August 1st or 2nd. She became dysregulated
during the home pass and assaultive. The lack of medication may have been a
contributing factor to her behavior.
INVESTIGATION:
Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 8/10/2022. Youth A
reported she went on a home pass without enough of her Vyvanse. Youth A went
2

on her home pass on 7/27/2022 and was scheduled to return to the facility on
8/3/2022 however returned a day early on 8/2/2022. Youth A was not aware she did
not have enough Vyvanse when she left the facility. Youth A became aware when
she was given her medication by her pre-adoptive dad on 8/1/2022. Youth A noticed
one of her pills was missing. Youth A reported she knows what her pills look like
and informed the pre-adoptive parents. Youth A reported she has run out of
medications a few times while at the facility however did not recall when.
Nurse 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 8/10/2022. Nurse 1
reported Youth A ran out of Vyvanse on Sunday 7/31/2022. Vyvanse is a class 2
drug that cannot be filled early by the pharmacy. Youth A’s Vyvanse is not for mood
or behavior. Nurse 1 became aware Youth A did not have enough Vyvanse to cover
the time she would be off ground on a home pass through email. Nurse 1 was
unable to recall the date he became aware of the specifics regarding the email.
Youth A’s Vyvanse prescription can only be refilled 3 days before the prescription is
scheduled to start for the month. Youth A’s July prescription was picked up from
Hometown Pharmacy on 6/30/2022 resulting in the August prescription being able to
be filled at the earliest on 7/28/2022. Youth A left for her home pass on 7/27/2022
and her medications were packed by Staff that morning. Youth A was on her home
pass when August’s prescription was picked up from Hometown Pharmacy on
7/29/2022. Nurse 1 reported Youth A ran out of her Vyvanse and would not have
had her medication on 8/1/2022 and 8/2/2022. Youth A receives her Vyvanse daily
at the facility.
Nurse 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 8/16/2022. Nurse 2
reported Youth A went on a home pass with not enough of her prescribed Vyvanse.
Youth A’s Vyvanse was not able to be filled until 7/28/2022 due to it being a
controlled medication and Youth A left for the home pass prior to the medication
being filled. Nurse 2 reported it is not normal protocol to send a youth on a home
pass with not enough medications. Nurse 2 was not aware of any other incidents
where Youth A ran out of medications at the facility.
Staff was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 8/16/2022. Staff reported
Youth A went on a home pass the end of July into the beginning of August. Staff
packaged Youth A’s medications for the home pass and there was not enough
Vyvanse for the days Youth A was going to be on the home pass. Staff notified
nursing and was informed via email and through discussion with Nurse 2 the
medication could not be filled yet. Nurse 2 advised Staff to send Youth A with the
Vyvanse that covered her through 7/31/2022. Staff reported this was the first time in
9 years working at the facility that she has encountered this situation. Staff gave the
medications and the Resident Medication Inventory Sheet to the Transportation
Coordinator. Staff did not count and review the medications with the Transportation
Coordinator per internal policy and procedures.
Supervisor was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 8/10/2022. Supervisor
did not recall the specific dates Youth A was scheduled to be on her home pass
3

however reported Youth A returned on 8/2/2022, a day earlier then she was
supposed to due to behaviors at the pre-adoptive foster home. Supervisor spoke
with the pre-adoptive parents about Youth A’s behaviors however the pre-adoptive
parents did not mention anything about medications. Supervisor was aware that
Youth A did not have enough of her Vyvanse for the entire time she was scheduled
to be on her home pass however did not recall when she learned this information.
Supervisor indicated staff packed Youth A’s medications for the home pass.
Supervisor was not aware of any other time Youth A ran out of medications.
Supervisor reported protocol is the Transportation Coordinator is to notify the pre-
adoptive parents of any medication information when dropping off youth and
medication and completing Resident Medication Inventory sheet.
Transportation Coordinator was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
8/10/2022. Transportation Coordinator transported Youth A to her home pass on
7/27/2022. She had Youth A’s medication and provided it to the pre-adoptive
parents. Transportation Coordinator did not recall if there were not enough of the
Vyvanse for the days Youth A was going to be on the home pass. She did not recall
anyone telling her that Youth A was short Vyvanse for 8/1/2022 and 8/2/2022.
Transportation Coordinator provided the pre-adoptive parents with Youth A’s
medication, they did not count the medications, the pre-adoptive parents signed the
Resident Medication Inventory sheet. Transportation Coordinator reported she
would not know Youth A’s Vyvanse was short as she goes by what is listed on the
form and does not know what the youth are prescribed to take when. Pre-adoptive
parents did not state there were not enough Vyvanse for Youth A.
Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 8/10/2022.
Administrator was not aware Youth A did not have enough of her Vyvanse
prescription for the time she was scheduled to be on her home pass. Administrator
reported that it is not facility protocol to send a youth without all their medication for
the time the youth is on their home pass.
Complainant was interviewed via phone on 8/9/2022. Complainant reported this
was not the first time that Youth A has ran out of medications. Complainant is
concerned that this is a pattern at the facility as Youth A ran out of medications the
last two days of June.
Documents Reviewed:
 Youth A’s current medication list dated 8/12/2022 states Youth A is prescribed
the following:
1. Clonidine HCl (clonidine hcl) 0.1 mg, tablet, take 1 tab morning,
afternoon, and bedtime, Qty: 93, Refills: 1, Issued: 6/30/2022.
2. Vyvanse (lisdexamfetamine) 40 mg, capsule, take 1 capsule morning,
Qty: 31, Refills: None, Issued: 6/30/2022.
3. Trazodone (trazodone) 100 mg, tablet, take 1 tab bedtime, Qty: 31,
Refills: 1, Issued: 6/30/2022.
4

 Medication Administrator Record (MAR) for Youth A from April 2022-August
2022. August MAR does not have anything filled in for 8/1/2022 or 8/2/2022
regarding Youth A receiving her Vyvanse prescription. June MAR notes Youth A
did not get her prescribed Trazodone 100 MG tablet and Clonidine HCL 0.1 MG
tablet at bedtime due to the medication being given earlier in the month for a
missing dose. May MAR indicates that Youth A did not have her medication on
5/17/2022-5/18/2022 and notes N in the boxes. N is used to document other and
then to be explained in the notes of the MAR. There is no documentation in the
notes for 5/17/2022 or 5/18/2022. April MAR indicates Youth A did not get her
Risperidone .05 MG tablet, Clonidine HCL 0.1 MG tablet, and Trazodone 50 MG
tablet at bedtime on 4/13/2022 and 4/18/2022 as the boxes are left blank and
there are no notes documented for these dates. March MAR indicates Youth A
did not get her Vyvanse 50 MG capsule on 3/17/2022 as the box is left blank and
there is not an explanation in the notes. Youth A did not get her Risperidone 1.5
MG tablet on 3/31/2022 as this box is blank and there is not an explanation in the
notes.
 Ashmun Sherk- Eagle Village policy and procedure for inventorying and ordering
medication states medications are inventoried weekly and submitted to medical
staff via email. Medical staff is responsible for coordinating with the pharmacy
and ordering all medications. This is completed to ensure that medications do
not run out prior to the weekend so that the amount of medication needed for
weekend home visits are available.
 Ashmun Sherk- Eagle Village policy and procedure for packing medication for
home visits and/or authorized overnight visits states up-night staff or designee
pack medication on the evening before the residents’ scheduled off-campus visit
and completes the top portion of the Youth Medication Transfer Form. The
appropriate number of medications will be packed to cover days resident will be
off campus. Upon hand off to the transporter, the authorized staff will review and
count the packed medication with the transporter, and both sign off for the
youth’s medications. The transporter will review and count the packed
medications with the parent/legal guardian’s responsible for medication
administration during the home visit and both sign off for the youth’s medication.
 Resident Medication Inventory Sheet for Youth A dated 7/27/2022 lists 4-
Vyvanse 40mg capsules with dosage instructions of 1 capsule at morning.
Transportation Coordinator signed off on the Resident Medication Inventory
Sheet as the person receiving and verifying the medications. There is a section
to check yes or no for medications being counted in presence of responsible
person that is not completed. The pre-adoptive parent signed the form.
5

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written health
service policies and procedures addressing all of the
following:
(e) Dispensing medication.
(g) Methods for dispensing medication when the
resident will be off site.
ANALYSIS: The facility is found in non-compliance as the youth was sent on
a home pass without the prescribed amount of Vyvanse to cover
the length of time the youth was supposed to be on the home
pass. The facility did not follow internal policy and procedure to
ensure the amount of medication needed for the home visit was
available, the appropriate amount of medication was not packed
to cover days the youth would be off campus, transportation
coordinator was not aware there were not enough medications,
and the transportation coordinator did not review and count the
medications the with individuals responsible for medication
administration during the home visit.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
It was recommended to the agency a protocol be put into place
that if medications need refills that are unable to be obtained
prior to a home pass due to the length of time the youth will be
gone, arrangements will be made to get medications to the
individual responsible for medication administration while the
youth is on the home pass prior to running out. Medication
Administrator Record’s should be checked regularly to ensure
the form is filled out completely and notes are documented as
the form direction states.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6

IV. RECOMMENDATION
I recommend upon receipt of an acceptable corrective no change be made to the
license status of this child caring institution.
08/19/2022
________________________________________
Jennifer Pastorick Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
August 19, 2022
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
7
